In New-Preston, on the 26th uIt. Matthew Elliot, Esq aged 66 Mir. F.. had been declining some time. On the 24th he returned from Haven, whther he went to consult Dr. Smith, the 26h he arose with his usual health apparently seated himself by the re ] and immediately fell from his chair and expi- red.

 In New-Preston, Genessee co. N. Y. June Ist Mrs. Sally Frink, daughter of Mir. Gideon Sooddard of this tOWn.

 Drowned, on Thursday afternoon, in the Basin at Albany, a man named Edwark Clark, native of Lin colnshire, England. He with his sister and brother

 naw, had just arrived there from England via New York, on his way to the western part of this state where he intended to settle, and in attempting to jump from the tow boat De Witt Clinton, before she was sufficiently near the wharf, he fell in the water and was not found till life had left him.

 In Sudbury, Vt. on the 31st ut. of cancer, Mrs. Thankful Burr. in the one hundred and second year of her age. This lady retained wonderful degree during life, her physical strength and faculties and she performed after having compassed an hundred years such feats of manual labor as would have been deemed sufficient in the prime of life. She emgrated from Granby Conn. during the winter, while in her 93d year, to her sons in Sudbury, where she deceased. But the glory of her history that the hoary head found in the ways ofrigheoushess. Her hope in the Saviour: and after having numbered sum of years allotted to few of the children men, she ly fell asleep in Jesus. af

 UPON the petition of William c. Abernethy and Elisha Smith, Guardians OfSophia D, HoadIy and Lu- ther Hoadly minors, of HarwintOn in said District, showing this Courtthat said Minors own the inter- est hereinafter mentioned in the following described real estate, situate in the town of Winchester the n- erest of said Minors in the whole being subject to the ncumbrance of the life estate of their mother, Sophia Abernethy, Qate Sophia Hoadyl in the one undivided third part thereof viz:

 About three fourhs of an acre of land lying on the East Branch ofSd River, about half mile north of Winsted Meeting House, in said town of Winchester. wl.h dwelling house and shed standing thereon.

 Also Slxy-seven rods of land lying eastofthe piece above described

 Also, the one undivided half of seven acres of land owned in common with Riley Whiting, lying on the East branch of said Still River, and north of the hiph way leading to Wallings hiI

 Also, one undivided half of GristiMiI, and theone undivided half of seven eghts of the mill privilege. and the one undivided half of small mill house. with about one half of an of land on which said mill and min house stand.

 Also the one half of Clock Shop, and the one half Of seven eights of the water privilege ohe same with the one half of small piece of land on which said shop stands, and that which adoins the same which has heretofore been occupied as a lumber yard.>

 Also, the undivided third part of fifteen acres of land lying in said Winchester, on the EastBank of said Still River, bounded north on Halsey Burr and Riley Whiting :---praying for liberty to sell the same, as her petition on file, dated May 4, 1897.

 Whereupon this Court doth order that said petit;op . be continued to the second Monday in September next at ten o'clock, A. to be heard before this Court at the Probate Office in Ltchfeld in sad Dis rlct and that notice of the pendancy of said petition be given by publishing this order in newspaperprin- ted m said Lltchfeld three weeks successivelya least SIX weeks before said second Monday in September next true Copy of Record. FREDERICK WOLCOTT, Judge. s

LEAVES Poughkeepsie every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, at o'clock A. M., passes through Sha- it meets the Hartford, New-Haven, and Albany sta ges.

 The proprietors of this line having provided good coaches and horses and careful drivers and reduced the fare, respectfully solicit share of public patron age.

 Seats taken at BUSH'S, Poughkeepse, and at s. DEMING'S, LitchGeld.

and passed the following resolutions, viz :---

 That the Constitution forced upon this re- public by the military power of Bolivar, be null and void.

 That the late ministers are not worthy of the peoples confidence, end that new ones be appointed.

 That a General Congress be assembled on May lst, to elect President, and form a con stitution for Peru.

 That General Santa Cruz remain President of the Republic until Congress shall assem- ble.

"THE SOUVENIR" will be published every We'd nesday morning, on extra-medium fine white paper. printed with new and elegant type, and decorated in addition to the engravngs alluded to above with ma ny appropriate embellishments. Each No. will com prise eight pages cut stched and expressly adapted for binding. At the expiration of every year. Or at the close ofa voume subscribers will be furnished gratis with general index of the contents, and a handsomely engraved tlle-page.

 Price of subscription $2 50 per annum, payahle in advance Postmasters and others out of the city, pro- curing five subscribers and becoming responsible for the payment, will be entitled to sixth copy gratis

 The Copperplate embellishments be superinten- ded by the Publisher, and the typographical part of this work will be under the eSdusive directions of Messrs. Atkinson & Alexander;who have so long been known to the public able and enerprsng arlixans that it is entirely unnecessary to say that far they are concerned there be doubt ito the elegance of its execution and with regard his own share of the arrangements, the Publisher binds hmself incase he should fail to perform any essential of his u- dertaking to refund the price of suhscripton. M

 Agents will shortly be appointed in different parts of the United States until which time subscriptions will be received by PHILIP PRICE, Jr. No. 66 Lombard street. Philadelphia, to whom all orders must be a- dressed, post paid--And also by JUDAH DOBSON, 108 Chesnut street; at the Office of the SATURDAY EVENING POST, No. 112 Chesnut street, two doors below the POst-Ofice.

 Post Masters, or other gentlemen, ordering six copA res of the work, will receive one copy gratis,

Court of Probate for the District of LitchfeId hath assigned Tuesday the 18th day of in stan July at ten o'clock in the forenoon, at the Pro- bate Office in Litchfeld for the examination and set clement of the administration account of the subscri ber Executor of the last will and testament of Joseph Mansfield late of said Litchfeld deceased, at which time and place all persons interested in said Estate will if they cause attend before said court and be heard in the premises. By order of said Court.

 JOHN T. MANSFIELD, Erecmor.

They have been seen ly tc Argo and Elizabeth, the latter only arrived this day.

When we have been requested by the chiefs or people to give instructions or advice, we have uniformly and perseveringly withheld it on all points where we could not refer the decision of the question either to the scrip lures, or to the uniform practices of christian nations. But where the scriptures are plain, or the practices of christians uniform, we have felt, and still feel. at liberty to speak with freedom, although we are opposed by the prejudices of the people, and the practices of the profigate.

 We have incucated on the ceiefs not only the common duties of morality, but we have also taught them that he who ruleth must he just ruling in the fear of the Lord; and have endeavOured to convince them that they are set for the punshme mt of evil dOers, and for the praise of them that do well. We have given them general principles derived from the word of God, together with script ure ex amples of their application and when these have not been clearly understood, and they have asked further explanations, we have sometimes referred them to modern examples in christian nations. We have thus pursued one undeviated course, neither withholding instruction, nor interfering with their author ity as rulers of the land.

 We have not been blind to their defects, by which they have sometimes screened the guilty from deserved punishment, neglected their promises, and even encouraged iniquity. We have sometimes too known of their chil dish, i'll timed and improper punishment, and more improper threats. But while we have with sorrow witnessed these things, we have also felt, that should we interfere with direct and positive remonstrances and advice, we should not only go beyond the limits of our instructions, but should also incur the dis pleasure, both of the rulers themselves, and also of all those who are witnesses of our dp- crations.

 While we have thus been endeayouring, both from the scriptures and the example of pious kings,to point out to the chiefs their du- ty Gs rulers, we have also endeavoured from the same authorities, to inculcate on the people their duties as subjects. We have taught them that they ''must needs be subject, not only for wrath, but also for conscience's sake," rendering to all their dues.' We have also distinctly held up the doctrine of the apostles, "that if any did not work neither should he eat"

 We have to all both chiefs and people, in- sisted not only on belief of the doctrines, but also obedience to the precepts of the bi- ble, including justice, honestA, integrity, pune tualisy, truth. purity, good order, union, kind ness and peaee.-These we have always told them, are signs of good heart and evidence ofa preparation for heaven. We appeal to all our candid observers, and to an enIlghten- ed public, whether the objects accomplished are not worthy the exertions we have made

 Is it nothing that the vices of the drunk ard and the gambler, with which the land was formerly almost overrun, should now be lm ited, to a comparatively small number !-that She observance of the sabbath should be al most universal !-that schools should be es- fablished in every part of the islands, and be attended by 25.OOO scholars among whom have been circulated more than 40, 900 tracts, containing various texts of scripture besides the decalogue, and all intoxicating the duties mentioned above Is it nothing that nearly all the chiefs and leading persons on the isl ands, and many others too, should be taught to read and write so as to correspond by let ter ? ls!t nothing that thousands who former iy devoted their time to gaming, quarreilng. and the practice of iniquity in all it's varied forms: and the thousands who wasted f eir days in idleness, should now be assembled in schools, and spend their leisure time ID read ing scripture tracts, and listening to nstruc- tion [? Is 1t nothing that number of leading persons in nation, as well as several others of lower rank, should publicly declare their belief m the doctrines. and render obedience to the precepts of the bible If all this is mo- thing, then we confess that our labors have been vain, and our object is proved unwor- thy the patronage of the wise or even of the benevolent.

 While we allude to these changes, we are far from being blind or indifferent to the bar barism, fickleness, duplicity. neglect, laziness, and other varied vices and crimes, which to some extent still remain, and which are more or less visible even to transient visiter; nei- ther do we vindicate or in the least degree offer paliatIon for these things. We only complain and remonstrate against these H. liberal and unmanly charges, by which the mission IS made accountable for the daily blunders, the childish actions. the long estab- lshed customs, and even the inheritent depra vity of the people; and all forsooth because we attempt to make them better.

 If the doctrines and duties of christianity in which the church of England, the church of Scotland, the Presbyterian and other churches Tn America are agreed, are not a. dapted to correct the evils which exist in hea then nations ;-if these doctrines and duties, when faithfully taught by precept and exam pie, have no good influence to cure the hu- man heart, and to promote virtue, order and happiness in society, then the missionary, ,and the Philanthropist too, may sit down togeth- CT in dlspair, and pronounce the evils among heathens incurable for if these fail, we may VNn1 ! I

lowing information.

 "On the eIst March, Lord Cochrane, af- ter the letter he had written to the Assembly of Castri, declared to all the Grecian Chiefs that he should depart immediately, if their disputes were not put an end to. This threat had the desired effect. The two assemblies have decided to re-assemble at ParOs-The most obstinate chiefs have consented to aban- don (at least for the mOment) their preten- ! sions and all misunderstanding has ceased On the 24th March, very bloody affair Oc- cured before Athens. Karaiskaki has been slightly wounded in the forehead. An i'm pOrtant position was carried by the Greeks. On the 24th March, in the evening, Lord Cochrane departed from Egina, with Tom bas, accompanied by four other vessels. On the 25th the steam boat came to take sup ply of coals for 25 days. Miaulis has receiy- ed an order to reiOin Lord COchrane with 9 other vessels.--The expedition IS secret. Some of the sailors imagine that it is direct ed against Alexandria, others agaist Candia. The vessel of Capt. Alfnate, sent from Leg horn, arrived on the 23d of March, at Egina. She carried 5000 balls, 100 barrels of pow der and l2O mil4ters of flour. A portion of these stores have been embarked on board the vessels forming the secret expedition. - Lord Cochrane has communicated to Kara ! iskaki, that if the siege of Athens was not raised on the 18th of April, he himself shonId make disposition to succor the beseiged, and attack the Turks. Miaulis and Tombasi have written to M. Eynard, to the effect that they would do all in their power to assist Lord Cochrane, and they asked nothing but to serve under his orders. General Church was setting out to join Karaskaki.

 'All the Greek newspapers, and particular " that published at Hydra, are filled with joy at the arrival of Lord Cochrane. The re-es- tablshment ofFabvier is confirmed" Smyrna, April 1S-ln order to put a stop to the many piracies which ruined commerce and navigation, the commanders of the En- 1 gIish, French, and Austrian squadrons have agreed together to determine in what places and channels ships belonging to these squad rOns shall constantly cruise.

 French Army in Spain.-Orders have been issued by the minister of War for the Army of Observation to retrograde to the same dis tance from the frontiers as the armies of Eng land and Portugal are at present posted. These orders have been the result of the complaints made by Mir. Lamb to M. Lima, 1 with respect to the movements in advance of our army, which appeared to have no other object than to support the insurrection of FL { vas and extend t to other places on the from tiers of Port agal-Lon. Com.

 Insurrectioe in one Of tue Burn,Gn Provinces Our English papers, furnish us with an ac- count of this insurrection from which we de- rive the following facts: Hostilites, at the last dates were in active progress. The Taens had gained an advantage, but not so decided one as was at first supposed. In the begin ing of December, the Governor of the Man taban district had sent 700 men to aid the Viceroy at Rangoon, and these. with 700 of his troops, marched to Syria strongly stock aded town. A division it burnt Kemmen- dine. as yell as the suburb of Takali, and 800 boats. A strong party of Taliens occu- pied strong position near the town, at the last dates. The Pegu colors were hoisted at DalIa.

 The salary paid to the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland every wear is 97.O0Oi. and the salary and fees paid to his Chief Secretary amOnnt to about 60O0l.

 The National Debt of Great Britain now amounts to eight hundred and ninety seven millions.

 PoLGr Erpedition.-Early in April, 1897, Captain Parry embarked in the HeckIa, for the purpose ofagain attempting to reach the North Pole. The NavigatOrs proceed to Hammerfest in Norway, where some rein deer will be provided for them to assist in drawing the boats on the ice when they are used as sledges. Upon the arrival of the Hecla at Spitzbergen, after securing her firm ly, she will be left to the charge of a lieuten- ant &c. The expeditions, into which the rest of the officers, and the crew are to be divided. will then start on their adventur- ous routes. The first, which is to proceed direct for the North Pole, is to consist of two parties ten men eaclfsand two officers, in two boats, which may be used on the ice with wheels or as sledges. The second division is under Lieutenant Foster, R. N., an officer of great scientific attainments it is his intcn- ton, if possible to sail around Sptzbergen. It having been correctly ascertained to be an island he will lay down the exact portions of the different bearings and make many astro- nomical observations and experiments in magnetism. The adventure thus far exceeds in boldness. any thing which Captain Parry has yet undertaken. It is calculated that he will have to travel little less than 1000 miles,pro- vided he and his companions reach the pole, carrying with them the whole of their neces- sares. Should the vessel be able to penetrate to eighty degrees, it would be 500 miles in a straight line to the Pole, which 1t is not prob able they could pursue, as they must be con stantly making detours, to avoid mountains of ice, or perhaps land. They are however almost sanguine ofsuccess, and expect to re-

 Bills of indictment have been found by the Grand Jury of one of the counties of New York, against the Judge for non-attendance and neglect of duty.-At the opening of the Circuit Court in Canandaigua, on the fourth ult Judge ThroOp charged the Grand Ju- ry especially in reference the abduction of MOrgan; and urged upon that body the necessity U! continuing

 the investigation of the affair until the offenders brought to justice. Two of the witnesses were exam ined by the Jury but nothing was discovered, no presentment was made,

 Fsre at PhiladelpI,ia.-A nest of small brick and l frame houses at the junction of P Pumb and Fourth streets, was destroyed early on the morning of the llth ult. The fire broke out between one and two o'clock in stable, and spread thence m different directions, destroying twelve houses on Plumb and Fourth streets, besides back buildings.

 ] Jara-The Janus arrived at Salem Mass. from Ba- 1 tava, informs, that the rebellion of the natives was very general throughou the isand On the lst of March, they had advanced within 30 or 40 miles of Sa- marang. The coloniss were obliged to divide their expected sOoo troops % from Holland, by May or June l The War in China--Verbal information is brought by the ship New-Jersey, arrived at Philadelphia from | Canton that the War which has recently broke out in the Chinese Empire has assumed more serious 1 aspect, and is extending. The Emperor has made considerable drafts on the Hong and salt merchants for assistance in protecting the country. What effect may be produced the coming crop of Tea is doubt ] full.

 Northern Discoueries.--Capt. Beecly who was sent l to Bhering's Straits to meet Capt. Franklin, could proceed farther than Kotzehues Sound, and turn ed south on the 18th Oct last. He did not meet Capt. F. who 1t is known set out on his return m August 1 last. Capt. B. lost men within Bherings Straits. He proposed going to the Sandwich Islands and Can | spring. He is not expected in Eng. before June 1898.

 Connecticut sabbath School Umiom.-The Sd annual report says ''The number of Auxilaries connected ! with us, one year since, was 5, including l2OO Teachers and 1000 Scholars. We now have 80 Auxiliaries, 1869 Teachers, who receive no reward for their services except the satisfaction ofknowng that they n the path of duty and of usefulness, | The number of Teachers connected with the Con- nectcut Union, who have become hopefully pious the year past, is l4l-the number of scholars 127-toal, 268''

 Christian Aimanac for 1828-A seperate edition of this Almanac is already engaged for Boston, Mass; Hartford, Conn.,; Rochester and Utica, N. Y.; Bat- more, Md.; Fredericksburgh, Va.; Wilmington N. C.; Charleston,S. C.; Augusta, Ga; Huntsville, Alabama The Committee will also issue edition " For the United States, adopted for convenient use in every part of the country"

 We learn from a Philadelphia Gazette that Capt. Synnes has been for some time detained at Trenton, N. J. by severe illness. Pecuniary aid is solicited through the medium of Wm l.. Pratt, Esq. editor of the Trenton True American, to enable him to reach his residence in Ohio. The admirers of Symmes the ory have opportunity of assisting their great captain to reach more desirable point than that to which he has beeen vrgng, in his lectures for some years past. We doubt not they will exercise their

 beray on this occasion. The captain has been beating the bush' in various parts of the country but present appearances indicate that his sagacious pupil, Mir. Reynolds, will finally "catch the bird."

 We hear from New-York that worthy member of the honorable board of Brokers was horsewhipped in Wall-street on Wednesday last, by director of one the facetious editor of the Enquirer:-

 "Board of Brokers.-Wall-street was in great bus tie yesterday morning. Transactions in Stocks, were carried on with more than their usual spirit. Ger tain transfers made by great dealer to anoh- CT to such amount that the latter staggered the ground under the weight of the burden. He carries the certificate of transfer, very ledgibly written in black and whae. Both belong to "good Society,"" and both good fellows, but they deserve be set the stOcks for making such fuss about stocks"

Joseph Lamcaster,-the celebrated founder of the Lancasteran system of instruction, arrived at New Haven few days snce from the island of St. CroiX He has been travelling in dferenEparts of South A. merica for several years and has attempted to intro duce his schools in Caracas and other places in Co., lumba. His plans, we understand, have not been successful, and he has left that country dissatisfied.

Judge Throop charged the Grand Ju- " especially in reference to the abduction of Morgan; and urged upon that body the necessity o continuing the investigation of the affair until the offenders were brought to justice. The fire broke out between one and two o'clock in a stable, and spread thence in different directions destroying twelve houses on Plumb and Fourth streets, besides back buildings.

Captain Knap, of the Mary Jane, at Newburyport, from St. Pierres reports that there never was so dry a season before known, in Martinique; not drop of rain has descended for than six weeks and veg itation entirely parched up the planters were in despair-the cut was but oae third grown--they asked 40 sous for moIasses the estates, and there would be but little at that price. The Mary Jane waited 50 days and could procure but 5000 gallons.

Northern Discoueries.-Capt. Beeclay, who sent to Bherings Straits to meet Capt. Franklin, could proceed no farther than Kotzehue's Sound and turn

 ed south on the 18th Oct last. He did not meet Capt.

 F., who it is known set out on his return in August last. Capt. B. lost men within Bhering's Straits. He proposed going to the Sandwich Islands and Can ton for supplies, and renewing the attempt in the spring He is expected in Eng before June 1928.

PedeStrianism.--A young gentleman, merchant in Maiden lane, started last Saturday morning. the 18th inst. at o'clock, ldayightl on visit his friends in Connecticut. He breakfased at New-Rochelle at 7, dined at Norwak at halfpas 1, took tea at Fair field g. and arrived home at Sratford at 20 minutes past 10 in the evening" distance of 65 miles. He 19 hours and 20 minutes on the road, hours and minutes of winch were devoted to resting leaving l6 and an half hours travelling tlme.-E. Post.

 Another " Charlottesville analogy between the opposition to Mir. Cannings administration, and that the administration of Mr. Adams, is remarkably stri- king. Both were organised by the factious and dis appointed, before the character of either could be tested by single measure: Both present the strange anomoly of uniting the leaders of the proud arstacra- cy with the rabbe, headed by the Cobbetts and Hunts of both countries Both are mere personal opposi- tions, without regard to measures or principles ;- Both administrations composed of and sustained by, the moderate and considerate of all parties: And both propositions conducted in spirit of unexamped ferocy, and bitter and cruel as the grave Extract gta letter Co the Editors o te Baltimore Con- merciaL Chronicle dated

 HAVANA, 27th of May, 1927.

 Present F. woLCoTT, Esq. Judge.

 UPON the petition of William c. Abernethy and Elisha Smith, Guardians OfSophia D, HoadIy and Lu- ther Hoadly minors, of HarwintOn in said District, showing this Courtthat said Minors own the inter- est hereinafter mentioned in the following described real estate, situate in the town of Winchester the n- erest of said Minors in the whole being subject to the ncumbrance of the life estate of their mother, Sophia Abernethy, Qate Sophia Hoadyl in the one undivided third part thereof viz:

 About three fourhs of an acre of land lying on the East Branch ofSd River, about half mile north of Winsted Meeting House, in said town of Winchester. wl.h dwelling house and shed standing thereon.

 Also Slxy-seven rods of land lying eastofthe piece above described

 Also, the one undivided half of seven acres of land owned in common with Riley Whiting, lying on the East branch of said Still River, and north of the hiph way leading to Wallings hiI

 Also, one undivided half of GristiMiI, and theone undivided half of seven eghts of the mill privilege. and the one undivided half of small mill house. with about one half of an of land on which said mill and min house stand.

 Also the one half of Clock Shop, and the one half Of seven eights of the water privilege ohe same with the one half of small piece of land on which said shop stands, and that which adoins the same which has heretofore been occupied as a lumber yard.>

 Also, the undivided third part of fifteen acres of land lying in said Winchester, on the EastBank of said Still River, bounded north on Halsey Burr and Riley Whiting :---praying for liberty to sell the same, as her petition on file, dated May 4, 1897.

 Whereupon this Court doth order that said petit;op . be continued to the second Monday in September next at ten o'clock, A. to be heard before this Court at the Probate Office in Ltchfeld in sad Dis rlct and that notice of the pendancy of said petition be given by publishing this order in newspaperprin- ted m said Lltchfeld three weeks successivelya least SIX weeks before said second Monday in September next true Copy of Record. FREDERICK WOLCOTT, Judge. s

full articles.headline:
POUGHKEEPSIE, SHARON

 AND LITCHFIELD
full articles.article:
LEAVES Poughkeepsie every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, at o'clock A. M., passes through Sha- it meets the Hartford, New-Haven, and Albany sta ges.

 Leaves Litchfeld every Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday, at o'clock A. M. and arrives at Pough- keepse in time to take the for New ork Albany.-Passcngers in this line will arrive in AL bany the morning after leaving Litchfed in time to take the morning stages for the west.

 The proprietors of this line having provided good coaches and horses and careful drivers and reduced the fare, respectfully solicit share of public patron age.

 Seats taken at BUSH'S, Poughkeepse, and at s. DEMING'S, LitchGeld.

 WILLIAM STEVENS & Go. Proprietors.

 N. B.-Al goods and baggage at the risk of the owners. er

 June, 1897. AG tf3

and passed the following resolutions, viz :---

 That the Constitution forced upon this re- public by the military power of Bolivar, be null and void.

 That the late ministers are not worthy of the peoples confidence, end that new ones be appointed.

 That a General Congress be assembled on May lst, to elect President, and form a con stitution for Peru.

 That General Santa Cruz remain President of the Republic until Congress shall assem- ble.

full articles.article:
"THE SOUVENIR" will be published every We'd nesday morning, on extra-medium fine white paper. printed with new and elegant type, and decorated in addition to the engravngs alluded to above with ma ny appropriate embellishments. Each No. will com prise eight pages cut stched and expressly adapted for binding. At the expiration of every year. Or at the close ofa voume subscribers will be furnished gratis with general index of the contents, and a handsomely engraved tlle-page.

 Price of subscription $2 50 per annum, payahle in advance Postmasters and others out of the city, pro- curing five subscribers and becoming responsible for the payment, will be entitled to sixth copy gratis

 The Copperplate embellishments be superinten- ded by the Publisher, and the typographical part of this work will be under the eSdusive directions of Messrs. Atkinson & Alexander;who have so long been known to the public able and enerprsng arlixans that it is entirely unnecessary to say that far they are concerned there be doubt ito the elegance of its execution and with regard his own share of the arrangements, the Publisher binds hmself incase he should fail to perform any essential of his u- dertaking to refund the price of suhscripton. M

 Agents will shortly be appointed in different parts of the United States until which time subscriptions will be received by PHILIP PRICE, Jr. No. 66 Lombard street. Philadelphia, to whom all orders must be a- dressed, post paid--And also by JUDAH DOBSON, 108 Chesnut street; at the Office of the SATURDAY EVENING POST, No. 112 Chesnut street, two doors below the POst-Ofice.

 Post Masters, or other gentlemen, ordering six copA res of the work, will receive one copy gratis,

\ THE Hon. Court of Probate for the District of LitchfeId hath assigned Tuesday the 18th day of in stan July at ten o'clock in the forenoon, at the Pro- bate Office in Litchfeld for the examination and set clement of the administration account of the subscri ber Executor of the last will and testament of Joseph Mansfield late of said Litchfeld deceased, at which time and place all persons interested in said Estate will if they cause attend before said court and be heard in the premises. By order of said Court.

 JOHN T. MANSFIELD, Erecmor.

 By his authorized Agent,

 3 ELIHU HARRISON.

In St. Michacls Church, in this village, on the Both ult: by the Rev. Mir. Stone, Mr. Jesse Osborn Miss Abigail Baldwin.

 Also, in this town, by the same, Mir. Henry Baldwin to Miss Hannah Cable.

They have been seen ly tc Argo and Elizabeth, the latter only arrived this day.

 I.abOrde, with fVe heavy figaics, is only waiting wind io get out We shall haye no d0Hbi, an engage men, before many days.

When we have been requested by the chiefs or people to give instructions or advice, we have uniformly and perseveringly withheld it on all points where we could not refer the decision of the question either to the scrip lures, or to the uniform practices of christian nations. But where the scriptures are plain, or the practices of christians uniform, we have felt, and still feel. at liberty to speak with freedom, although we are opposed by the prejudices of the people, and the practices of the profigate.

 We have incucated on the ceiefs not only the common duties of morality, but we have also taught them that he who ruleth must he just ruling in the fear of the Lord; and have endeavOured to convince them that they are set for the punshme mt of evil dOers, and for the praise of them that do well. We have given them general principles derived from the word of God, together with script ure ex amples of their application and when these have not been clearly understood, and they have asked further explanations, we have sometimes referred them to modern examples in christian nations. We have thus pursued one undeviated course, neither withholding instruction, nor interfering with their author ity as rulers of the land.

 We have not been blind to their defects, by which they have sometimes screened the guilty from deserved punishment, neglected their promises, and even encouraged iniquity. We have sometimes too known of their chil dish, i'll timed and improper punishment, and more improper threats. But while we have with sorrow witnessed these things, we have also felt, that should we interfere with direct and positive remonstrances and advice, we should not only go beyond the limits of our instructions, but should also incur the dis pleasure, both of the rulers themselves, and also of all those who are witnesses of our dp- crations.

 While we have thus been endeayouring, both from the scriptures and the example of pious kings,to point out to the chiefs their du- ty Gs rulers, we have also endeavoured from the same authorities, to inculcate on the people their duties as subjects. We have taught them that they ''must needs be subject, not only for wrath, but also for conscience's sake," rendering to all their dues.' We have also distinctly held up the doctrine of the apostles, "that if any did not work neither should he eat"

 We have to all both chiefs and people, in- sisted not only on belief of the doctrines, but also obedience to the precepts of the bi- ble, including justice, honestA, integrity, pune tualisy, truth. purity, good order, union, kind ness and peaee.-These we have always told them, are signs of good heart and evidence ofa preparation for heaven. We appeal to all our candid observers, and to an enIlghten- ed public, whether the objects accomplished are not worthy the exertions we have made

 Is it nothing that the vices of the drunk ard and the gambler, with which the land was formerly almost overrun, should now be lm ited, to a comparatively small number !-that She observance of the sabbath should be al most universal !-that schools should be es- fablished in every part of the islands, and be attended by 25.OOO scholars among whom have been circulated more than 40, 900 tracts, containing various texts of scripture besides the decalogue, and all intoxicating the duties mentioned above Is it nothing that nearly all the chiefs and leading persons on the isl ands, and many others too, should be taught to read and write so as to correspond by let ter ? ls!t nothing that thousands who former iy devoted their time to gaming, quarreilng. and the practice of iniquity in all it's varied forms: and the thousands who wasted f eir days in idleness, should now be assembled in schools, and spend their leisure time ID read ing scripture tracts, and listening to nstruc- tion [? Is 1t nothing that number of leading persons in nation, as well as several others of lower rank, should publicly declare their belief m the doctrines. and render obedience to the precepts of the bible If all this is mo- thing, then we confess that our labors have been vain, and our object is proved unwor- thy the patronage of the wise or even of the benevolent.

 While we allude to these changes, we are far from being blind or indifferent to the bar barism, fickleness, duplicity. neglect, laziness, and other varied vices and crimes, which to some extent still remain, and which are more or less visible even to transient visiter; nei- ther do we vindicate or in the least degree offer paliatIon for these things. We only complain and remonstrate against these H. liberal and unmanly charges, by which the mission IS made accountable for the daily blunders, the childish actions. the long estab- lshed customs, and even the inheritent depra vity of the people; and all forsooth because we attempt to make them better.

 If the doctrines and duties of christianity in which the church of England, the church of Scotland, the Presbyterian and other churches Tn America are agreed, are not a. dapted to correct the evils which exist in hea then nations ;-if these doctrines and duties, when faithfully taught by precept and exam pie, have no good influence to cure the hu- man heart, and to promote virtue, order and happiness in society, then the missionary, ,and the Philanthropist too, may sit down togeth- CT in dlspair, and pronounce the evils among heathens incurable for if these fail, we may VNn1 ! I

lowing information.

 "On the eIst March, Lord Cochrane, af- ter the letter he had written to the Assembly of Castri, declared to all the Grecian Chiefs that he should depart immediately, if their disputes were not put an end to. This threat had the desired effect. The two assemblies have decided to re-assemble at ParOs-The most obstinate chiefs have consented to aban- don (at least for the mOment) their preten- ! sions and all misunderstanding has ceased On the 24th March, very bloody affair Oc- cured before Athens. Karaiskaki has been slightly wounded in the forehead. An i'm pOrtant position was carried by the Greeks. On the 24th March, in the evening, Lord Cochrane departed from Egina, with Tom bas, accompanied by four other vessels. On the 25th the steam boat came to take sup ply of coals for 25 days. Miaulis has receiy- ed an order to reiOin Lord COchrane with 9 other vessels.--The expedition IS secret. Some of the sailors imagine that it is direct ed against Alexandria, others agaist Candia. The vessel of Capt. Alfnate, sent from Leg horn, arrived on the 23d of March, at Egina. She carried 5000 balls, 100 barrels of pow der and l2O mil4ters of flour. A portion of these stores have been embarked on board the vessels forming the secret expedition. - Lord Cochrane has communicated to Kara ! iskaki, that if the siege of Athens was not raised on the 18th of April, he himself shonId make disposition to succor the beseiged, and attack the Turks. Miaulis and Tombasi have written to M. Eynard, to the effect that they would do all in their power to assist Lord Cochrane, and they asked nothing but to serve under his orders. General Church was setting out to join Karaskaki.

 'All the Greek newspapers, and particular " that published at Hydra, are filled with joy at the arrival of Lord Cochrane. The re-es- tablshment ofFabvier is confirmed" Smyrna, April 1S-ln order to put a stop to the many piracies which ruined commerce and navigation, the commanders of the En- 1 gIish, French, and Austrian squadrons have agreed together to determine in what places and channels ships belonging to these squad rOns shall constantly cruise.

 French Army in Spain.-Orders have been issued by the minister of War for the Army of Observation to retrograde to the same dis tance from the frontiers as the armies of Eng land and Portugal are at present posted. These orders have been the result of the complaints made by Mir. Lamb to M. Lima, 1 with respect to the movements in advance of our army, which appeared to have no other object than to support the insurrection of FL { vas and extend t to other places on the from tiers of Port agal-Lon. Com.

 Insurrectioe in one Of tue Burn,Gn Provinces Our English papers, furnish us with an ac- count of this insurrection from which we de- rive the following facts: Hostilites, at the last dates were in active progress. The Taens had gained an advantage, but not so decided one as was at first supposed. In the begin ing of December, the Governor of the Man taban district had sent 700 men to aid the Viceroy at Rangoon, and these. with 700 of his troops, marched to Syria strongly stock aded town. A division it burnt Kemmen- dine. as yell as the suburb of Takali, and 800 boats. A strong party of Taliens occu- pied strong position near the town, at the last dates. The Pegu colors were hoisted at DalIa.

 The salary paid to the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland every wear is 97.O0Oi. and the salary and fees paid to his Chief Secretary amOnnt to about 60O0l.

 The National Debt of Great Britain now amounts to eight hundred and ninety seven millions.

 PoLGr Erpedition.-Early in April, 1897, Captain Parry embarked in the HeckIa, for the purpose ofagain attempting to reach the North Pole. The NavigatOrs proceed to Hammerfest in Norway, where some rein deer will be provided for them to assist in drawing the boats on the ice when they are used as sledges. Upon the arrival of the Hecla at Spitzbergen, after securing her firm ly, she will be left to the charge of a lieuten- ant &c. The expeditions, into which the rest of the officers, and the crew are to be divided. will then start on their adventur- ous routes. The first, which is to proceed direct for the North Pole, is to consist of two parties ten men eaclfsand two officers, in two boats, which may be used on the ice with wheels or as sledges. The second division is under Lieutenant Foster, R. N., an officer of great scientific attainments it is his intcn- ton, if possible to sail around Sptzbergen. It having been correctly ascertained to be an island he will lay down the exact portions of the different bearings and make many astro- nomical observations and experiments in magnetism. The adventure thus far exceeds in boldness. any thing which Captain Parry has yet undertaken. It is calculated that he will have to travel little less than 1000 miles,pro- vided he and his companions reach the pole, carrying with them the whole of their neces- sares. Should the vessel be able to penetrate to eighty degrees, it would be 500 miles in a straight line to the Pole, which 1t is not prob able they could pursue, as they must be con stantly making detours, to avoid mountains of ice, or perhaps land. They are however almost sanguine ofsuccess, and expect to re-

 Bills of indictment have been found by the Grand Jury of one of the counties of New York, against the Judge for non-attendance and neglect of duty.-At the opening of the Circuit Court in Canandaigua, on the fourth ult Judge ThroOp charged the Grand Ju- ry especially in reference the abduction of MOrgan; and urged upon that body the necessity U! continuing

 the investigation of the affair until the offenders brought to justice. Two of the witnesses were exam ined by the Jury but nothing was discovered, no presentment was made,

Y. His plans we understand, have not been successful, and he has left that country dissatisfied

 Fsre at PhiladelpI,ia.-A nest of small brick and l frame houses at the junction of P Pumb and Fourth streets, was destroyed early on the morning of the llth ult. The fire broke out between one and two o'clock in stable, and spread thence m different directions, destroying twelve houses on Plumb and Fourth streets, besides back buildings.

 ] Jara-The Janus arrived at Salem Mass. from Ba- 1 tava, informs, that the rebellion of the natives was very general throughou the isand On the lst of March, they had advanced within 30 or 40 miles of Sa- marang. The coloniss were obliged to divide their expected sOoo troops % from Holland, by May or June l The War in China--Verbal information is brought by the ship New-Jersey, arrived at Philadelphia from | Canton that the War which has recently broke out in the Chinese Empire has assumed more serious 1 aspect, and is extending. The Emperor has made considerable drafts on the Hong and salt merchants for assistance in protecting the country. What effect may be produced the coming crop of Tea is doubt ] full.

 Northern Discoueries.--Capt. Beecly who was sent l to Bhering's Straits to meet Capt. Franklin, could proceed farther than Kotzehues Sound, and turn ed south on the 18th Oct last. He did not meet Capt. F. who 1t is known set out on his return m August 1 last. Capt. B. lost men within Bherings Straits. He proposed going to the Sandwich Islands and Can | spring. He is not expected in Eng. before June 1898.

 Connecticut sabbath School Umiom.-The Sd annual report says ''The number of Auxilaries connected ! with us, one year since, was 5, including l2OO Teachers and 1000 Scholars. We now have 80 Auxiliaries, 1869 Teachers, who receive no reward for their services except the satisfaction ofknowng that they n the path of duty and of usefulness, | The number of Teachers connected with the Con- nectcut Union, who have become hopefully pious the year past, is l4l-the number of scholars 127-toal, 268''

 Christian Aimanac for 1828-A seperate edition of this Almanac is already engaged for Boston, Mass; Hartford, Conn.,; Rochester and Utica, N. Y.; Bat- more, Md.; Fredericksburgh, Va.; Wilmington N. C.; Charleston,S. C.; Augusta, Ga; Huntsville, Alabama The Committee will also issue edition " For the United States, adopted for convenient use in every part of the country"

 We learn from a Philadelphia Gazette that Capt. Synnes has been for some time detained at Trenton, N. J. by severe illness. Pecuniary aid is solicited through the medium of Wm l.. Pratt, Esq. editor of the Trenton True American, to enable him to reach his residence in Ohio. The admirers of Symmes the ory have opportunity of assisting their great captain to reach more desirable point than that to which he has beeen vrgng, in his lectures for some years past. We doubt not they will exercise their

 beray on this occasion. The captain has been beating the bush' in various parts of the country but present appearances indicate that his sagacious pupil, Mir. Reynolds, will finally "catch the bird."

 We hear from New-York that worthy member of the honorable board of Brokers was horsewhipped in Wall-street on Wednesday last, by director of one the facetious editor of the Enquirer:-

 "Board of Brokers.-Wall-street was in great bus tie yesterday morning. Transactions in Stocks, were carried on with more than their usual spirit. Ger tain transfers made by great dealer to anoh- CT to such amount that the latter staggered the ground under the weight of the burden. He carries the certificate of transfer, very ledgibly written in black and whae. Both belong to "good Society,"" and both good fellows, but they deserve be set the stOcks for making such fuss about stocks"

Joseph Lamcaster,-the celebrated founder of the Lancasteran system of instruction, arrived at New Haven few days snce from the island of St. CroiX He has been travelling in dferenEparts of South A. merica for several years and has attempted to intro duce his schools in Caracas and other places in Co., lumba. His plans, we understand, have not been successful, and he has left that country dissatisfied.

F;ye at Philadeiphia.-A nest of small brick and frame houses at the junction of P umb and Fourth streets was destroyed early on the morning of the 1lth ult. The fire broke out between one and two o'clock in a stable, and spread thence in different directions destroying twelve houses on Plumb and Fourth streets, besides back buildings.

Jara-The Janus arrived at Salem Mass. from Ba- tava, informs, that the rebellion of the natives was very general throughout the island On the lst ot March, they had advanced within 30 or 40 miles of Sa- marang. The colonists were obliged to divide their forces, to meet them at many points. The coonists expected 5000 troops from Holland, by May or June

American Tract Society-The total receipts from May 2 to June 1, inclusive, $5, ,43387; from the following sources, viz. Captain Knap, of the Mary Jane, at Newburyport, from St. Pierres reports that there never was so dry a season before known, in Martinique; not drop of rain has descended for than six weeks and veg itation entirely parched up the planters were in despair-the cut was but oae third grown--they asked 40 sous for moIasses the estates, and there would be but little at that price. The Mary Jane waited 50 days and could procure but 5000 gallons.

Northern Discoueries.-Capt. Beeclay, who sent to Bherings Straits to meet Capt. Franklin, could proceed no farther than Kotzehue's Sound and turn

 ed south on the 18th Oct last. He did not meet Capt.

 F., who it is known set out on his return in August last. Capt. B. lost men within Bhering's Straits. He proposed going to the Sandwich Islands and Can ton for supplies, and renewing the attempt in the spring He is expected in Eng before June 1928.

PedeStrianism.--A young gentleman, merchant in Maiden lane, started last Saturday morning. the 18th inst. at o'clock, ldayightl on visit his friends in Connecticut. He breakfased at New-Rochelle at 7, dined at Norwak at halfpas 1, took tea at Fair field g. and arrived home at Sratford at 20 minutes past 10 in the evening" distance of 65 miles. He 19 hours and 20 minutes on the road, hours and minutes of winch were devoted to resting leaving l6 and an half hours travelling tlme.-E. Post.

 Another " Charlottesville analogy between the opposition to Mir. Cannings administration, and that the administration of Mr. Adams, is remarkably stri- king. Both were organised by the factious and dis appointed, before the character of either could be tested by single measure: Both present the strange anomoly of uniting the leaders of the proud arstacra- cy with the rabbe, headed by the Cobbetts and Hunts of both countries Both are mere personal opposi- tions, without regard to measures or principles ;- Both administrations composed of and sustained by, the moderate and considerate of all parties: And both propositions conducted in spirit of unexamped ferocy, and bitter and cruel as the grave Extract gta letter Co the Editors o te Baltimore Con- merciaL Chronicle dated

 HAVANA, 27th of May, 1927.

 Seven sail are now of. They are supposed to be the Colombian squadron, consisting oftwo Irigates one corvette two brigs, and three u,asted schooner
